title: Unbound pages – design for reading onscreen
content:
Some on this list might be interested in the article I just wrote for _The Magazine_ about the typography of ebooks and design for the screen – or rather, for a plethora of screens:

[http://the-magazine.org/13/unbound-pages](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014223504/http:/the-magazine.org/13/unbound-pages "http://the-magazine.org/13/unbound-pages")

Although _The Magazine_ is subscription based, non-subscribers can read the full text of one article a month.

John
author: johndberry

comments.content:
John, it's always interesting reading your pieces, and this one is intriguing as well, althought, paradoxically, on my screen it doesn't look good at all - in The Magazine site I see very long lines of text and no margins!

That said, about the specific issue of your article, the few reading experiences I had with e-books (even those made by corporate publishers) were disappointing. I wonder if there isn't a way to transfer (translate?) a book design layout made with, say, Indesign, to a tablet or an e-reader device, for example using the pdf format which still seems to be the best for rendering books layout (by the way, didn't Amazon introduce a sort of "as printed" e-books format?)

Nicola – You can certainly do that, but then what you get is a _static_ layout, which only works if you're viewing it on an appropriately sized and oriented screen. What I’m talking about is _flexible_, adaptive layout. And having the tools to design that well.

\> I see very long lines of text and no margins

The margins look fine on my computer (Mac using Safari).

Very clearly written and expressed, without being condescending - nicely done. I certainly agree that it's high time reading software took layout seriously. BTW, I like the "return-from-footnote" links!

One thing I'd love to see properly implemented is multiple columns. The main question there is: how do you reconcile that with vertical scrolling? Here's an idea: don't. Scroll _horizontally_ instead! :-) In fact the human existence -including our reading "hardware", from the acuity of the retina to the structure of the neck- is much stronger in the horizontal dimension. The ancient scroll was right on.

hhp

Hrant – Pagination based on the actual screen you’re reading on would eliminate the need for “scrolling” as we use it now. Instead, you’d page down (or over) from one multi-column page (if that’s appropriate to the screen size & shape) to the next.

But you’re quite right that multiple columns on a “page” larger than the screen makes no sense whatsoever.

John
